conclusion: The wire ab is suspended in a uniform magnetic field B perpendicular to the plane of the paper and into the paper. The wire has a length L. A current I flows from a to b.

When a current I flows through the wire in a magnetic field B, a magnetic force F_m acts on the wire. The magnitude of the magnetic force is given by F_m = I L B. The direction of the force is determined by the right-hand rule, directed upwards.

When the current I flows from a to b, the magnetic force F_m = I L B acts upwards. The reading of one of the spring scales, F1, is the weight of the wire minus the magnetic force: F1 = W - I L B, where W is the weight of the wire.

When the current is reversed and its magnitude becomes 2I, the current flows from b to a. The magnetic force now acts downwards: F_m = 2I L B. The reading of one of the spring scales, F2, is the weight of the wire plus the magnetic force: F2 = W + 2I L B.
From the first scenario: F1 = W - I L B. From the second scenario: F2 = W + 2I L B.
Subtract the first equation from the second: F2 - F1 = (W + 2I L B) - (W - I L B) = 3I L B.
Solve for B: B = (F2 - F1) / (3I L).
The magnitude of the magnetic induction intensity B is: B = (F2 - F1) / (3I L).
